awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Evaluation of post-wildfire effects on soil physical and chemical properties in response to the Caldor and Tamarack fires near Lake Tahoe
awd_abstract_narration:
Wildfire-induced changes to soil properties impact infiltration, runoff, and soil erodibility in fire-prone areas. Recent wildfires in the eastern Sierra Nevada mountains provide a unique opportunity to quantify fire effects on soil properties in natural field settings. These wildfires represent a new generation of large high-temperature canopy fires that are likely to increase in frequency in this region due to changing climate. Reduced infiltration and enhanced runoff after fire are directly related to changes in the structure and surface chemistry of the pore system within the soil. Fire effects on soil physical and chemical properties have been quantified mostly in the laboratory but not in natural field settings. This project will quantify the effect of two large wildfires (Caldor and Tamarack) on soil physical and chemical properties to better understand how fires affect hillslope hydrologic processes (infiltration, runoff, erosion), fire-related secondary risks such as flooding and debris flows, and forest management practices related to fire activity.

This project will quantify post-fire changes to soil physical and chemical properties to better understand their impact on post-fire runoff, infiltration, and erosion in natural settings. Samples will be collected from burned and unburned locations both to measure soil hydraulic and thermal conductivity functions via controlled evaporation experiments and to identify functional groups in soil organic matter that influence soil hydrophobicity using proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry. Additionally, infiltration and soil hydrophobicity will be measured in-situ using infiltrometer tests. Results will be presented to local stakeholders of fire-prone watersheds to guide forest management and improve the sustainability of water and ecosystem resources. Results will be transferable to watersheds in the Sierra Nevada with similar soil conditions. This project will provide research opportunities for an early career scientist, field training to a Ph.D. student, and hands-on experience for an undergraduate student.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Caldor fire was one of several “megafires” that burned in the Sierra Nevada mountains of eastern California and Northern Nevada during Summer 2021. The Caldor fire itself was responsible for 221,835 acres that, in combination with intense rainfall events resulting from an atmospheric river event later that fall, resulted in numerous landslides and debris flows that impacted watershed function and infrastructure in the region. Our research team took advantage of the extreme event to investigate the impacts of a megafire on soil physical and chemical properties. In particular, we implemented a field sampling plan that was designed to obtain minimally disturbed core samples from both burned and unburned (control) soil from the field for laboratory analysis and comparison. We also carried out water drop penetration time (WDPT) tests at multiple sites, and collected bulk samples of soil and ash for additional testing. Tests included measurements of soil aggregate size distribution, texture, hydraulic and thermal properties. We also measured apparent contact angles (ACA) to quantify soil hydrophobicity and carried out Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to characterize the chemical properties of the organic substances in the soil that cause hydrophobic conditions. This suite of analyses allowed us to investigate the principal relationships between physical properties of burned samples (compared to similar unburned soil), soil structure, and hydrophobicity. 

 

We tested the hypothesis that changes to soil hydrophobicity, soil structure, and soil thermal properties could be quantified to improve our understanding of the relationships between post-fire soil physical and chemical properties and  decreased infiltration, enhanced runoff, soil erosion, flooding, and debris flows during and after intense storm activity following a fire. Our preliminary observations revealed that changes to soil structure via combustion of soil organic matter were detectable when soil aggregate distributions were compared between burned and control samples. We observed reduction of overall aggregate size as well as a reduction in overall soil organic matter that typically acts to increase aggregate stability and improve soil structure. We found that the observed reduction in organic matter corresponded to increased ability for the soil material to transmit heat, a relationship that has not been explicitly documented previously for fire-affected soils. We also found significant differences in soil hydrophobicity between burned and unburned soils in terms of WDPT and ACA, even though the unburned soil was already hydrophobic (ACA >90°). We did not readily detect changes to soil water retention and hydraulic conductivity functions, which are considered “hydraulic indicators” for soil structure alterations, except perhaps in the narrow, saturated range of the soil water retention curve data. This suggests that, for this soil and burn situation, water infiltration, and more importantly, surface water runoff, is primarily a function of hydrophobicity after a fire, especially for coarser soils in relatively dry settings. Our chemical analysis of soil samples is ongoing, but we hope to document the principal organic compounds responsible for soil hydrophobicity with the aim of developing a technique to quantify fire-induced hydrophobicity in soils.
